item.title: 8 aspects of feeling
item.description: Pleasant feeling, painful feeling, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling. This is feeling Sense contact is the proximate cause of feeling Craving is the way leading to the emergence of feeling Ending of contact, ceases feeling instantly This Noble Eightfold Middle Path is the way to cease feeling The delight and joy of feeling: This is the satisfaction within feeling That feeling is impermanent, subject to change and suffering: This is the danger in feeling The removal and elimination of desire and lust for feeling: This is the escape from feeling (from Samyutta Nikaya 36)

item.title: 8 deliverances
item.description: Experiencing forms on one’s own body, one visualizes internal forms, as if they were external, (e.g. an organ, bone, tooth, or nail).

item.title: 8 kinds of Higher Knowledge
item.description: Insight Knowledge Power of creation by mind Psychic powers Divine power of hearing Knowledge of the minds of others Knowledge of past existences Divine power of sight Knowledge of extinction of moral intoxicants

item.title: 8 Nutriments for Ignorance
item.description: Monks, and ignorance too, I declare, is a specific condition. And due to its nutriment, it manifests. I declare: Ignorance has its nutriment: the five hindrances.

item.title: 8 qualities of the True Dhamma
item.description: Qualities that lead to dispassion, not to passion Qualities to being unfettered, not to being fettered Qualities to shedding, not to accumulating Qualities to modesty, not to self-aggrandizement Qualities to contentment, not to discontent Qualities to seclusion, not to entanglement Qualities to aroused persistence, not to laziness Qualities to being unburdensome, not to being burdensome

item.title: 8 Worldy winds
item.description: The eight worldly phenomena that tend to make the heart tremble: 1. Gain 2. Loss 3. Respect 4. Contempt 5. Praise 6.

item.title: 8-Fold Middle Path
item.description: Right Understanding (samma ditthi) Right Thought (samma sankappa) Right Speech (samma vaca) Right Action (samma kammanta) Right Livelihood (samma ajiva) Right Effort (samma vayama) Right Mindfulness (samma sati) Right Concentration (samma samadhi) (from Samyutta Nikaya 12.
